facts.fact: The documentary 'The Thinking Machine' was produced to commemorate MIT's 100th anniversary in 1961.
The film features interviews with AI pioneers including Jerome Wiesner, Oliver Selfridge, and Claude Shannon.
Jerome Wiesner served as a science advisor to President JFK and was the President of MIT.
The documentary explores the early days of artificial intelligence and the concept of 'thinking machines'.
The film was hosted by actor David Wayne.

sources.title: The Thinking Machine 1961 Documentary (full) - YouTube
sources.snippet:
# The Thinking Machine 1961 Documentary (full)
## Mike Gargan
276 subscribers
35 likes

### Description
1340 views
Posted: 6 Mar 2025
The Future of AI in 1961? A Look Back at MIT’s Vision of Thinking Machines 

This rare episode of CBS’s Tomorrow series, produced to commemorate MIT’s 100th anniversary (1861–1961), explores the early days of artificial intelligence, robotics, and the potential of “thinking machines.” Hosted by actor David Wayne, this documentary-style special features interviews with pioneering computer scientists, including MIT President Jerome B. Wiesner and AI visionary Oliv

sources.title: The Thinking Machine (Artificial Intelligence in the 1960s)
sources.snippet:
# The Thinking Machine (Artificial Intelligence in the 1960s)
## Roberto Pieraccini
200 subscribers
1334 likes

### Description
126764 views
Posted: 31 May 2010
Can machines really think? Here is a series of interviews to some of the AI pioneers, Jerome Wiesner, Oliver Selfridge, and Claude Shannon. A view at the future of computer intelligence from back then...

65 comments
### Transcript:

Barry O'Sullivan

Professor, University College Cork • Visiting Professor, Northwestern University • Fellow AAAI, EurAI, MRIA • Director, Insight & CRT in AI • Chair, National Research Ethics Committee, Medical Devices • Track II Diplomat

sources.title: The Thinking Machine (Artificial Intelligence in the 1960s) | Barry O ...
sources.snippet:
2d 

   Report this post

A cute 1960s clip on "The Thinking Machine" and how AI would transform the world. Olly Selfridge, Claude Shannon and Jerome B. Wiesner. Wiesner was science advisor to JFK, co-founder of the MIT Media Lab, and eventually President of MIT. Selfridge and Shannon need little introduction being part of the legendary Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence in 1956 which gave the field its name. Clip:
